abstract.p: This article is a study of political economy of Gujarat in the context of the issues pertaining to ‘good governance’. The article reviews Gujarat’s socio-economic development with respect to key indicators of environment, health, education and welfare programmes. It presents an argument that overall economic growth alone is not the adequate criterion for assessing good governance. Rather, broader issues of human development, reach and depth of welfare programmes and the approach informing the economic policy constitute the core bases for the assessment of a state’s claims to good governance. Gujarat, one of the states of the Indian union, is seen as a developed state that has made considerable progress in more recent times in the direction of good governance. This article seeks to critically examine this impression.

body.p: The function of any government is to govern socio-economic affairs of society in its jurisdiction. Nature of its governance is closely related to (a) its mission and objective for preserving and/or developing nature of socio-economic and political order; (b) overall and sectoral policy formations, and (c) manner and modus operandi of management in executing policies. Overall policy postulates provide holistic perspective as well as approach of the government towards its priority for capital accumulation, distribution of resources, socio-cultural dimensions and role of the state therein. This is essentially a political task. Within this political framework, government prepares legislations for different sectors. Laws, rules and procedures follow. Next step is implementation of policy through macro as well as micro level management.

A premise of neo-liberal political economy school is that markets are the best engine to lift living standards and build shared prosperity. What is needed is ‘good governance’ for sustainable development so as ‘all can enjoy long, healthy and creative lives’ (UNDP, 2006).2 ‘Good governance’ and democracy are intertwined. In this system citizens and groups articulate their interests, mediate their differences and exercise their legal rights and obligations. Transparency in decision making process and accountability of the government at all levels enhance legitimacy of the rulers. Participation of citizens and civil society actors in governance at different stages is sine qua non for efficient and effective implementation of the policies. While participating in governance the stakeholders can assert their priorities and make the programmes need-based as well as community culture specific. They monitor, supervise and check bureaucratization as well as mal-practices at various levels.

This article is a study of nature of governance of one of the federal states of India, Gujarat. At the outset it needs to be emphasized that economic policies of the state government in India are largely circumscribed by the policies of the Government of India (GoI) under constitutional framework. Within this context, governance of different states in its cultural milieu, nature of civil society and politics needs examination. Gujarat has received several awards for ‘good governance’ from media and corporate foundations. It is now projected not only by the chief minister and his party but also a section of media that Gujarat under Narendra Modi’s leadership is the best governed state, and provides a model for India.

The question we address is: Does ‘good governance’ refer, in holistic sense, to all aspects of the government; or only to certain sectors of governance? The article is based on secondary data, micro studies of two cities and district social welfare administration and interviews with political leaders and bureaucrats (present and past).

sec.title: Gujarat: Economic Growth
sec.p: Gujarat is one of the industrialized states of India. It has on average 11 per cent industrial growth as against 9 per cent of all India; and contributes 14 per cent in India’s export. Not only in common parlance but also in academic discourse the term Gujarati (person) is synonymously used as a business entrepreneur; though vast majority of the population in Gujarat is not engaged in trade and commerce. Capital has been well-organized earlier in the form of guild and now in the form of modern associations. The state has a history of weak and fragmented socio-political movements of labour and deprived communities. The Congress was in power till 1995 with a brief break—Janata Morcha (alliance of non-Congress parties, 1976–1980) and Janata-Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) alliance (1989–1990). BJP rules the state since then. Approach to economic growth in the state has by and large remained the same irrespective of the party in power.

On the eve of its separation from the bilingual Bombay State, newly formed Gujarat was ranked the eighth among all the states of India in industrial growth. At that time, substantial Gujarati capital was concentrated in Mumbai. The first task that the Government of Gujarat (GoG) undertook was to replicate Bombay’s economic growth here. Consensus among the ruling elite and mainstream civil society prevailed for ‘orderly and rapid industrial development’ (Erdman, 1971, 1973; Shah, 1990; Sinha, 2005). A combination of capital as well as labour-intensive industrialization in diverse sectors was then a guiding view.

Beside attracting and facilitating private investment, the government preferred partnership with private investors in joint stock companies for capital accumulation. As early as 1962, the government set up Gujarat State Fertilizers and Chemicals Ltd. followed by several public sector industries. From the beginning, consensus among political leaders prevailed that the public sector should function as efficiently as the private sector, free from political interference (Erdman, 1973, p. 35).

Following the pattern of the former Bombay State, various innovative institutions to attract, promote and facilitate investment were set up in the early 1960s. Like other states, Gujarat also provided several incentives to investors including capital in the form of credit with low interest and also subsidy, tax exemption, tax deferment, etc. Institutional mechanism has been evolved to provide training in preparation of projects, marketing and other skills to young prospective entrepreneurs. District Industries Centres came into existence to disseminate information and assist the investors at the district level. Besides these inputs, the government acquired land for industrial estates and provided roads, water, electricity and other facilities to these locations. By 1982, more than three-fourth of the land in Gujarat was eligible for industries with special incentives by one criteria or another (Sinha, 2005). Government declared several areas as ‘notified area’ for industries under Gujarat Industrial Development Act 1962.

During the pre-neoliberal policy the state government evolved, what Aseema Sinha calls a ‘bureaucratic-liberalism’ model of strategic interaction with the central government to attract investment in Gujarat and also to guide investors. The actions of Gujarat’s bureaucracy unlike several other states embodied the classic developmental role of ‘guiding markets’ (ibid., p. 92). The bureaucrats had a free hand to find out ways and means with the central government so as the state gets more licenses and private investment. They were functioning like entrepreneurs, taking initiative, risk, collecting and collating data related to market and industrial production. An autonomous agency for industrial promotion, Industrial Extension Bureau, called iNDEXTb 9 ‘i’ is small representing small ego, so is ‘b’ for bureaucracy, indicating de-bureaucratic approach; Sinha, 2005: 301, fn 36) was formed in 1977. Its financial source has been made independent of state budget to keep it free from bureaucratic and political constraints.

The state government had set up offices not only in Delhi, but also in Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai and South Africa to attract capital. The officers wooed the businessmen and encouraged them to invest in Gujarat. In several cases the officers worked on behalf of investors to expedite the process of procuring license from the Union government. In some cases to expedite the process, bureaucrats used to take first a license in the name of the GoG and shift it to the joint sector. Later, its full ownership was transferred to the private party (ibid.).

Within a decade of its formation, Gujarat ‘made striking progress in its industrial economy’. Between 1974 and 1990 it was second highest in receiving the letters of intent (ibid., p. 56). The state attained third position in terms of number of industries and production in 1984–1985. In 1984–1985, among the 200 top giant industries of India, 24 were located in Gujarat. Madhavsinh Solanki, the then Chief Minister, as media often reported, had an ambition to turn Gujarat into ‘mini-Japan’. Under his stewardship ‘Gujarat became the second most industrialized state in India, as his government, in cooperation with the private sector, launched many projects in power development, electronics, fertilizer and many other industries (Wood, 1995, p. 158).’

sec.title: 1990s and After
sec.p: Anticipating the change in the GoI’s economic policy, the GoG announced ‘Incentive Policy’ for the industries by executive order in the early 1980s, and repeated the same with modifications in 1986 and 1990. Later, three industrial policies (2000, 2003 and 2009) have been announced. The first policy declared its target to compete with Southeast and East Asian countries. In the post-2002 communal riots, under the Modi government, industry policy got blended with cultural uniqueness and pride: Gujarat has ‘cultural base’ where you ‘sow a rupee, reap a Dollar’ (GoG, 2003, p. 3). To boost up spirit of enterprising dominant Gujaratis, the state declares: ‘to provide business leadership to entire world’. The policy also announces, ‘Good Governance (is): A way of life for Government in Gujarat’ (GoG, 2003, p.10).

All the three policies promise: (a) to remove all bottlenecks presumably obstructing investment, (b) to simplify procedures, speeding of process and develop single window system for clearance and other related matters; (c) to change rules and laws to facilitate transferring agriculture land to non-agriculture land for industrial purpose; (d) to reorient administration to take up new challenges of globalization and attract more investment throughout the world; (e) to strengthen e-governance, data bank and dissemination of information for selection of projects; (f) to develop physical as well as human infrastructure (roads, power, water etc., and skilled human-power) to meet the requirements of the industries.

These policies provide subsidy varying from 25 to 40 per cent to industries. Besides reducing their sales tax, the exemption in sales tax from six to ten years has been offered. The government promises ‘to reform the tax regime’ so as to make the state globally competitive. Number of categories in tax concessions increased from the first to the third policy period. In 2009 new schemes for assistance for Micro3 and innovative, Small and Medium enterprises have been introduced. Moreover, foreign investors are also offered infra-structure facilities at low cost.

Infrastructure development Act was passed in 1999 to facilitate private investment and to ensure co-ordination among various Government agencies a Board was setup. The Act has been amended in 2006 empowering the Government to extend the concession period beyond 35 years and to approve financial assistance up to 20 per cent cost of the project.

Besides increasing number of industrial estates they are upgraded with adding infrastructure facilities. The State Industrial Parks and Special Economic Zones (SEZs) have developed with extra facilities to stimulate export-oriented industries. Sixty SEZs have been approved. Ports are developed to encourage export. India’s first private port, Gujarat Pipavav Port Ltd., is being developed to support cargo handling.

The state is actively engaged in acquiring land for industrial development. Gradually it has amended laws related to agriculture land to facilitate industries. First, restrictions on purchase of agriculture land for non-agriculture purpose were removed in 1994. Rules for converting agriculture land to non-agriculture purpose were relaxed. Second, with government order in 2005 the state began to offer public land—waste as well as grazing land—to ‘big industries and individual progressive farmers’. They were expected to develop that land for productive purpose with the use of technology. Such land was given not only on lease without any rent for the first five years but beneficiaries are also permitted to mortgage it to banks for loan. Third, under the Land Acquisition Act 1894, the state also acquires land from private farmers for ‘public purpose’, and hand over that to industries. In Kutch and Saurashtra several hundred thousand hectares of government and private land has been given to big industries like Reliance and Adani.4 In fact, a few investors in the SEZ who got land on lease or at throwaway price have sold that land to others with high price (Yadav, 2011). Moreover, besides cheap water and electricity, a few industries received gas from the Gujarat State Petroleum Corporation, at rates below its cost price. Such favours, according to Comptroller and Auditor General (2012) cost the state ₹ 5000 crore. Not only that, the government has violated environmental laws, converting a protected wildlife sanctuary Kutch for industry. It has also manoeuvred around Coastal Regulation Zone laws for a private port to be built for the export of cement (Sud, 2012).

The officers in the Ministry of Industries and different industrial corporations of GoG have been always business friendly. During the license-quota-raj they found out ways and means to woo investors. Their enthusiasm increased under the neo-liberal policy. Most of them come from upper strata of society; hence they can very easily build rapport with entrepreneurs. Money power and social networks of the entrepreneurs match with bureaucrats’ mindset. Businessmen believe in keeping the bureaucrats in good humour. The Business India notes,
‘(I)f Gujarat is flooded with investment it is partly due to a corrupt but well-organized regime. Industrialists know that in Gujarat everything has a price. Land, water and power concessions, not to mention environmental clearances are hassle free if one has the right political connections. Similarly files move fast and lengthy duplicate procedures are simply non-existent if one knows which palms to grease’ (as cited in Sinha, 2005, p. 228).
On the whole the investors, in the past and today, are very happy with Gujarat’s bureaucracy and appreciate its efficiency.

In the 1960s, Gujarat was known for production of textiles. At present Chemicals and Petrochemicals have become major industries with 62 per cent share in the total industrial production of the state. Medium and large industries have increased nearly eight-fold between 1980s and 1990s. In the last decade, on an average more than six hundred new projects were sanctioned to launch. At the same time the condition of the small scale industries has not improved. A demand of small entrepreneurs in 2006 for creating separate wing within the Enterprise Commissioner’s office to pay attention to their problems, has not yet met. With such pro-industrial growth governance, Gujarat was at the top among Indian states with 11 per cent Gross Domestic Product (GDP) between 2001–2002 and 2005–2006. But now other states have picked up the growth and moving faster than Gujarat. In the last five years between 2006–2007 and 2010–2011 Gujarat’s GDP has declined by 9.3 per cent, occupying sixth position.5

sec.title: Pollution
sec.p: Major industrial belt between Vapi in south and Mehsana in north, called golden corridor is concentrated with chemical industries. It is the country’s most polluted area. Many industries dump their effluents in rivers, ponds and sea, or just throw in open space. They pollute water, air and soil. A few of them even illegally connect their outlet pipes to municipal sewage. Environmental laws are more often than not flouted.

The Industry Policy 2000 admitted that ‘the requirement of sustainable development entails the need to tighten the pollution control measures and environmental safety in the State’. It declares that ‘Along with strictly implementing the pollution and environment protection measures, the State would be striving to set right the irregularities in this regard, which has taken place in some industrial clusters’ (GoG, 2000, p. 8). The Minister for industries, admitted that ‘We are suffering because of the lack of proper planning in the past…We have to come out of it’. But the governance has remained as usual. No priority was expressed to tackle in the government’s the ‘Infrastructure Vision 2010’.

In the 1990s the government initiated and encouraged industries to develop ‘Common Effluent Treatment Plants’ (CETPs). These plants are largely supported by the public funds: 25 per cent of the cost was state subsidy; 25 per cent central government subsidy; 30 per cent loans from the financial institutes; and remaining 20 per cent paid by the industries. Most of the plants do not meet the norms prescribed by the Ministry of Environment and Forest of GOI (Prajapati, 2012). CAG Report 2010–2011 noted that ‘treated’ waste water out of CETPs had four to ten times more toxic than Government’s own norms in terms of biological oxygen demand (BOD) value, three times higher in case of chemical oxygen demand (COD) values and four times higher in terms of total dissolved salts (TDS). This has caused ‘large-scale death of aqua stock in the rivers’ in the recent past. On 7 May 2004 the Supreme Court observed, ‘…due to indiscriminate dumping of hazardous waste due to non-existent or negligent practices together with lack of enforcement by authorities, the ground water and, therefore, drinking water supplies have been effected/damaged’ (ibid.).

Not that the government is unaware of increasing adverse and deadly effects of pollution on the vast population. But it does not have courage to displease industrialists. It has a fear that strictly enforcement of the pollution control norms would go against the interest of the factory owners. And, it is feared that they would go away from Gujarat and may also discourage new investors to come to the state. The government which is obsessed with high economic growth and to become front-runner in the market is caught with contradictions of its own making.

sec.title: Employment and Labour
sec.p: Like industry agriculture in Gujarat is increasingly becoming capital—and technology—intensive. With infrastructure development in irrigation and power, agriculture production has increased. But small and marginal farmers are further marginalized and farm sector employment has declined. Rural labour is moving to non-farm sector where job opportunities have increased. But as the industries are capital-intensive rate of employment in manufacturing sector is slow and erratic. Employment per factory has significantly declined, from 99 workers per factory in 1960–1961 to 62.40 persons in 1990–1991 and to 59.44 per cent in 2005. Whereas average invested capital per factory has increased 2.5 times in less than a last decade (Hirway and Shah, 2011).

To attract investment the State has overtly and covertly undermined the existing labour laws which provide some protection to workers. The government has amended labour legislations to provide freedom to industry to employ labour on contract basis. Consequently, Ahmedabad has the lowest labour costs among the major cities in India, with labour costs less than 50 per cent of those in Delhi and 40 per cent below those in Pune. The wage bill for industry in Gujarat constitutes only 2.42 per cent of the invested capital. The same figure stands at 4.04 for Karnataka, 4.4 for Maharashtra, 4.94 for Andhra Pradesh, 5.42 for Haryana and 5.5 for Tamil Nadu.6 Sizeable labour force is in informal sector without social security and other benefits under the labour laws. Stipulated minimum wages by the GoG are lower in all occupations in Gujarat than Maharashtra and several other states (Breman, 2007; Mahadevia and Shah, 2012). Not only that but the Labour Commissioner’s office, whose responsibility is to implement labour laws and protect labourers’ interest, has been reduced in its strength—both in number and power. Its functioning is further weakened.

sec.title: Health Care Services
sec.p: Percentage on health expenditure to the total state budget has increased from 2.69 per cent in 2003–2004 to 3.69 in 2006–2007. It is the same in all the major industrialized states: Haryana, Punjab, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka. In terms of percentage of GDP and per capital expenditure on health Gujarat ranks eighth and ninth respectively among the major states.

The state provides primary health care services through local governments—municipalities in urban areas and district panchayats in rural areas. Number of primary health centres has increased from 142 in 1961 to 1096 in 2010. Each district has government hospital and all municipal corporations also run hospital(s) in their city. These institutions, besides providing primary health care and curative services, carry out centrally sponsored health programmes particularly reproductive child health and national health programmes. The performance of the immunization programmes is above 90 per cent. However, all sub-health centres do not have adequate infrastructure. More often than not operation theatres at Community Health Centres are used for family planning operations only. Users’ fee has been introduced, though families below poverty line (BPL) are exempted. It is observed that more often than not health centres do not have required medicine and the poor have no other way but to buy medicine from the market. Majority of the staff do not have residential quarters near workplace. And, one-fifth of the positions at different levels have been vacant for many years. Out of 1,135 sanctioned posts for specialist doctors, nearly 70 per cent are vacant.7 Ratio of doctors in public sector health care to population is 1:19000, as against 9000 in Tamil Nadu (Mavalankar and Satia, 2010).

Both the Central as well as Gujarat government have accepted policy to outsource health care services. In 2008, the government of India launched ‘Rastriya Swashthaya Bima Yojana’ (RSBY; National Health Insurance Scheme) with the support of the state governments.8 Its objective is to provide insurance cover to below poverty line (BPL) households for major diseases that involve hospitalization. The state government is responsible for execution of the programme. So far, the state has enrolled 49 per cent of the BPL families under the scheme. An exploratory study indicates that the insured patients often experience hassles between the insurance company and hospitals. It has been found that ‘the private insurer promotes more coverage as government pay them premium, but discourages claims as larger claims would turn out costly for them’ (Mahadevia and Shah, 2012). There is hardly any local administrative mechanism to monitor insurance providers as well as hospitals and to guide the beneficiaries.

Under public-private partnership, Chiranjeevi Yojana (long life scheme) has been launched by the GoG in 2006 to reduce Mother Mortality Rate (MMR). It is meant for pregnant women from BPL families. Private maternity homes and gynaecologists are involved with remuneration in child delivery for poor women. As an innovative scheme it has received awards but it has so far not been able to reduce MMR significantly. Its rank order remains sixth in MMR among all the states in 2011. This author’s fieldwork in an exploratory study (Shah, 2010) finds that often private maternity homes avoid taking complicated and risky cases. There is also a complaint that the doctors registered under the scheme also charge the patients over and above the fees from the government. The cases of the doctors registering ghost patients have also appeared in the media.9

sec.title: Private Health Care
sec.p: Private health care services are multiplying everywhere in the country and so in Gujarat too. Number of private hospitals has increased at phenomenal rate in the last three decades in the country. The private health care system is widely heterogeneous in terms of facilities, quality of doctors, diagnostic equipment as well as skill and charges. Poor families living in urban slums get treatment for common ailments from semi-qualified/quack medical practitioners. The condition of hospitals/maternity homes in terms of infrastructure has also great deal of variation. The general practitioners as well as many consultants hardly maintain records of the patients and the treatment given. Fees for general practitioner vary from ₹ 10 to ₹ 100, and for consultants from ₹ 250 to ₹ 800 per visit. The fees for hospital bed vary from ₹ 50 to ₹ 3000 + per day. Most of the private hospitals do not have basic infrastructure or personnel. More often than not they follow ‘medically unnecessary procedures’ and prescribe ‘excessive, expensive and more risky drugs’.

Gujarat government made an abortive attempt to monitor private health care system. Following the formation of the National Rural Health Mission, the Gujarat government has set up Gujarat State Health Mission in 2005, headed by the Chief Minister. In 2006 the government initiated to prepare health policy with two objectives: (a) improving access to, and utilization of health services; and (b) reorganization and restructuring of the existing health care infrastructure and delivery system. After prolonged consultations with civil society organizations, a draft of public health rules was prepared and circulated in early 2009. Among other things the rules had several provisions to monitor private health providers. Accordingly, all health care centres were expected—besides maintaining records of the cases—to display in Gujarati, types and availability of services, charges for consultation etc. Meanwhile, the state witnessed an epidemic of Hepatitis ‘B’ that took a toll of more than one hundred persons in February 2009. The reason was the use of infected syringes that had spread the virus as many clinics were not segregating bio-medical waste and were found violating the Biomedical Waste (M&H) rules 1998. The government booked six doctors for violating the Medical Practitioners Act. Eleven storehouses were served with notices for ‘improper segregation of bio-medical waste’.10 The government declared to invoke ‘mechanism’ which facilitates ‘inspection of private health care establishments’ by the local bodies. The doctors from all parts of Gujarat were up-in-arms against the proposed Act. They argued that ‘the induction of certain regulatory provisions will make medical treatment in rural and semi-urban areas beyond the reach of middle and lower middle classes.11 The government immediately succumbed to the pressure. The Health Minister declared, ‘The draft (Gujarat Public Health Act) is just placed for free and frank discussion, hence there is no room or cause for confrontation’. Since then the draft has been put in the deep freeze.12

Juvenile sex ratio in Gujarat has reached to 886 in 2011. Upwardly mobile families use modern technology for female foeticides. Though sex determination test is legally prohibited, it is widely practiced by some clinics which also provide facilities for abortion. The government has not been able to make significant dent in preventing the practice. Similarly, its performance in Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in comparison to other states has not improved significantly. Like elsewhere, IMR has declined in Gujarat from 57 in 2003 to 48 in 2009, but continues to lag behind Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Punjab, Maharashtra and West Bengal.13

sec.title: Education
sec.p: Primary education is supposed to be ‘free and compulsory’ under the State’s 1961 Act. By now, primary schools are available in all most all villages except few remote areas. Since 1984 female education has been free at all levels. The government also introduced mid-day meal scheme to arrest drop-out rate and develop integration among the children of different communities. Since 1997, village schools organize public celebration in the month of June to mobilize enrolment. And from 2002, to boost girls’ enrolment, Kanya Kelavani Rath Yatra (procession for girls’ education) is celebrated for three days in which all state officers including chief Minister participate. Moreover, Vidhyadeep Scheme providing life-insurance to the students studying in the Government schools up to class XII was launched in 2001.14 Moreover, girls’ parents of BPL families are provided with a bond of ₹ 1000 at the time of admission in the first standard in the urban area. With these efforts, school enrolment has now reached to nearly hundred per cent. But these incentives and once in a year mobilization are not sustained with follow up mechanism. The state’s budget allocation on education has remained ‘relatively static’ over the years.15 And its share in allocation for primary education has declined in the last decade (Hirway and Mahadevia, 2004; Pratham, 2012).

Like elsewhere, drop out rate at primary school level has been considerably arrested from 21 per cent in 2001–2002 to less than five per cent in 2011–2012 (MHRD 2011). Gujarat’s position however has sunk from sixteenth in 2001 to eighteenth in 2011 in terms of growth in literacy. Girls’ enrolment has remained low compared to boys at all levels. Despite a campaign called ‘Gunotsav’ to improve quality of education, the situation has not improved. 55 per cent of rural students in standard Vth cannot read a standard II level text and 65 per cent cannot do simple subtraction (Pratham, 2012). On an average, students–teacher ratio in primary schools remains 33:1. The government had stopped filling the vacant positions for primary teachers in 1995. After three years, in 1998 new appointments of the qualified teachers were made under the Vidhya Sahayak Scheme (VS) with ₹ 2500 salary (now increased to ₹ 5000 per month). Under the scheme no teacher is appointed as permanent. The earlier tradition of frequent supervision by the District Education Inspectors has become slack because of variety of reasons including inadequate staff. On the other hand, private schools and colleges have increased manifold. Except a few meant for elite class, most of them also do not provide quality education (Shah, 2012). The government is unable to monitor their fees, infrastructure and quality (Shah, Desai and Shah, 2008).

sec.title: Technical Education
sec.p: All the industry Policies of GoG emphasized a need to develop skilled human power for industry. With economic reform, like elsewhere, the number of institutions for higher education in Gujarat has increased three fold in the last decade. They are mainly related to technical education, management, commerce, Information technology and communication. According to the study in 2006–2007, 64 per cent engineering colleges were in private sector. In medical colleges private sector has 33 per cent share. During the last four years, the government has handed over six out of 12 government medical colleges to private, self-financed management. Both in the government and the private colleges the teaching staff is inadequate. Teacher–student ratio in technical colleges was 1:41 as against 1:23 at all India level (Basant and Mukhopadhyay, 2010). Most of the self-financed colleges do not have required staff. Nearly 50 per cent of these colleges have no full-time principal.16 34 per cent technical colleges in Gujarat are ranked below average (ibid.).

sec.title: Welfare Programmes for Poor
sec.p: Like in many states, proportion of people living below poverty line has declined at the rate of 8.6 per cent as against 20.2 per cent in Odisha, 12.3 per cent in Tamil Nadu, 9.7 per cent in Karnataka between 2004 and 2010. Number of BPL families as identified by the government remains unchanged. Central and the State government’s welfare programmes like subsidized food supply, old age pension, widow, the physically disabled and BPL families are managed by GoG. Micro studies show that several BPL households are left out of the list.17 So is the case with eligible poor old persons, widows and disabled. Procedures to get BPL card and/or certificate to avail pensions are cumbersome. Over a period of five decades the state has set up four Boards18 to implement various social security schemes for unorganized workers in different sectors. According to one estimate merely 0.40 of the total unorganized workers entitled under various schemes have been registered. Now the GoI has enacted a somewhat comprehensive, Unorganised Workers Social Security Act, in 2008. Responsibility for its implementation is with the state governments. The GoG took three years to form the State Social Security Board. Mechanism and rules for implantation are yet to be finalized. On the whole local administration, to say the least, is indifferent to the needs of the needy. The state spent as low as 0.48 per cent of the state budget or 0.04 per cent of GSDP for various social security schemes in 2009–2010 (Mahadevia and Shah, 2012). In such a scenario it is not surprising to find that as large as 44.7 per cent children under 5 years are underweight and 23.3 per cent children are undernourished. On Hunger Index Gujarat is in the ‘alarming category’, ranking thirteenth among 17 major Indian states (IFPRI, 2008).

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: Economic policy for growth that GoG follows, like all other states, is the same that Union government has evolved and adopted. Different states have worked out different strategies and institutional mechanism for implementing the policy. Thanks to historical and cultural milieu—dominance of entrepreneur class and its culture—Gujarat has always remained business friendly. It was the case even during the ‘licence quota raj’. Under the neo-liberal economic reforms Gujarat was the first state to declare its industrial policy to increase incentives and support structure to private investment for industries. Inducements have been multiplied in the last two decades. In the institutional structure capital investors are treated as the only stakeholders for industrial growth. They are involved in decision making and monitoring process. Labour has no place therein. Administrative procedures have gradually minimised. Bureaucrats are generally benign towards capitalist class. They are now professionalized and geared to follow the best practices of the corporate world into the government to accelerate economic growth euphemistically called ‘development’.19 Nevertheless, from the perspective of neo-liberal economy such governance may be qualified as ‘good’. Gujarat however is not the only state with high growth trajectory. Maharashtra, Haryana and Andhra Pradesh are at par or even ahead of Gujarat in GDP, investment and per capita income. Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Punjab are not far behind. Comparative studies on governance of these states would contribute in exploring political theory on economic development.

Nature of growth in Gujarat however has led to deterioration of natural resources and environment. Gujarat has polluted areas affecting water and air, plantation, animal life and human health. The GoG has been ineffective in controlling the industries for violation of pollution control laws. In fact the government itself has violated its own environmental laws. In the pre-reform period the industry policy was in favour of both capital—as well as labour-intensive production. Several laws protecting interests and well-being of labour have been scrapped or made ineffective. As investment in industry is largely capital-intensive; rate of creating employment is slow. Moreover, regular employment has declined.

The state has not yet formulated any policy perspective even within neo-liberal economy for education and health. Programmes and schemes in these sectors are ad hoc and piecemeal. Bureaucrats, a few exceptions apart, are not committed to the social cause. Ground level mechanism for implementation of welfare programmes is not as rigorous and dynamic as it is in the case of industrial sector. Overall performance of GoG in social sectors is not impressive. Several other states—both those which are leading in economic growth with Gujarat, particularly Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Punjab and Karnataka, and economically slow states like Kerala, Himachal Pradesh—are ahead in these sectors. The state has retrogressed in overall human development. It has slipped from tenth to eleventh rank in human development between 1999 and 2009. The system of governance in these sectors is not participatory. Social sector programmes are increasingly getting privatized under the garb of PPP. The objectives of the government and the private agencies in such partnership are not the same. The former focus on well-being of the people and for the latter the main concern is private profit. Moreover, the approach of the government towards people is that of ‘beneficiaries’, and not citizens having rights. Policymakers soft pedal with private partners. No effective mechanism to monitor the functioning of the private agencies has been evolved. The mainstream civil society in Gujarat is not geared to raise the issues of poverty and exploitation. And the civil society segments which have expertise and active engagement in health, education and livelihood issues are side-tracked or harassed by the government bureaucracy. Performance of GoG in social sector is poorer than the states with similar high growth trajectory. Measuring quality of governance on six dimensions (infrastructure service delivery, social service delivery, fiscal performance, law and order, judicial service delivery and quality of legislature) with several indicators, Gujarat is one of the better governed states among the six top. But it is not on the first rank. It moves between fourth and sixth position (Mundle et al. 2012).

The present state of affairs of lopsided governance is not only because of management system. It is primarily because of government’s approach and policy for social transformation to build desirable society. India’s and Gujarat’s model of governance primarily focus on economic growth rather than overall sustainable human development. Sensitive and committed administrative mechanism has not been built. Economic growth certainly has somewhat trickledown effect. A small section improves life chances and moves up. Reduction of abject poverty can be attained. In this trajectory a large number of people get lolly-pop and dream for future. They manage to survive. The system needs them as a reserve army of labour and as consumers. But since redistribution of growth and equality are not on agenda of the ‘good’ governance, inequality and disorder perpetuate endangering sustainable human development in varying degree under different regimes.
